title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The average score on a quiz

options.label: B
options.text: The probability of getting a question right

options.label: C
options.text: The number of possible outcomes

options.label: D
options.text: The number of possible ways to pair outcomes

multiple-choice.question: How many different ways can you write down answers for a 2-question true/false quiz?
What is the number of possible outcomes for a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the probability of getting a perfect score by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the average score on a 10-question true/false quiz if you and your friends always randomly guess at every question?
What is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing on a standardized test?

options.label: D
options.text: 1/95 trillion

multiple-choice.question: How many possible outcomes are there for a question on a standardized test if there are 5 possible answers?

What is the glue that connects people in a narrative, making it compelling and universal?

options.label: A
options.text: Facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: Personal stories

options.label: C
options.text: Official sources

options.label: D
options.text: Overview sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of unofficial sources in a well-reported piece of journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide numbers and answers to basic questions

options.label: B
options.text: They help to identify the big picture

options.label: C
options.text: They give insight into the why behind an event or trend

options.label: D
options.text: They are not necessary for a well-reported piece

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources

options.label: B
options.text: Overview sources

options.label: C
options.text: Unofficial sources

options.label: D
options.text: Experts

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of asking surprising questions in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To gather facts and data quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To identify what is compelling from what is chatter

options.label: C
options.text: To present bulleted facts and updates

options.label: D
options.text: D: To convey information in a slow dance of information

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of anecdotes in a narrative?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide exposition and facts

options.label: B
options.text: They breathe life into a grey story

options.label: C
options.text: They are not necessary for a well-reported piece

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used in urgent situations

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Only overview sources

options.label: C
options.text: Only unofficial sources

options.label: D
options.text: A trifecta of official, overview, and unofficial sources

multiple-choice.question: Why is it necessary to regard the stories of every subject as sacred in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To gather facts and data quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To identify what is compelling from what is chatter

options.label: C
options.text: To achieve the complicated, fragile human connection

options.label: D
options.text: To present bulleted facts and updates

options.label: A
options.text: To convey information quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To achieve the complicated, fragile human connection

options.label: C
options.text: To identify what is compelling from what is chatter

options.label: D
options.text: To regard the stories of every subject as sacred

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the narrative personal stories that contribute to the buffet of journalism and the information that needs to be conveyed quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: The narrative personal stories are only used in urgent situations

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The narrative personal stories have the luxury of a slow dance of information

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the artful solicitation of story in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey information quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To identify what is compelling from what is chatter

options.label: C
options.text: To achieve the complicated, fragile human connection

options.label: D
options.text: To make the journalism memorable and deliver the narrative bond that will connect us to each other
